question: If $\Delta=\begin{vmatrix}1&a&a^{2}\\ 1&b&b^{2}\\ 1&c&c^{2}\end{vmatrix}$ and $\Delta_{1}=\begin{vmatrix}1&1&1\\ bc&ca&ab\\ a&b&c\end{vmatrix}$ then
explanation: Multiply $R_1, R_2, R_3$ of $\Delta_1$ by $a, b, c$ respectively and divide by $abc$.
Take out $abc$ from $R_2$ and $a$ from $R_1$? No, take $abc$ from $R_2$.

$\Delta_1 = \begin{vmatrix}a&a&a\\ 1&1&1\\ a^2&b^2&c^2\end{vmatrix}$ (Wait, column vs row). The structure corresponds to $\Delta$ with row swaps. Swapping rows introduces a negative sign. $\Delta_1 = -\Delta$.
